title: Case 9 – The Newspaper Stand
brief:
Dawn warms the street but the pavement stays cold. A paperboy finds a body slumped beside the newsstand — coat open, pockets turned, briefcase gone like the others.
The owner swears he heard raised voices: one deep, confident, wearing a suit that didn't belong on a tired street.

Three names circle like headlines:
LAWSON — partner to too many dead men.
CAROL — archivist with a window view of every whispered deal.
ISSAC — workshop lights burning long past midnight.

Everyone calls it coincidence.
Coincidence is getting hard to believe.
wrenHint:
History repeats in sharper ink.

• Lawson survives again — richer each time someone falls.
• Carol hears voices but sees no fight; guilt leaves shadows, not words.
• Issac bought heavy cable last night — but no device is wired here.

Ask who profits from another missing briefcase.
Ask who keeps showing up alive when others don’t.

lawson: I walk that street every night. Habits hold a man together when the markets don’t. Last night I passed the stand — nodded, kept moving. Paper seller chats too much for midnight.
The victim was leverage — on banks, on rivals, occasionally on me. Killing leverage is like burning credit. Only fools and desperate men do it.
Fingerprints on benches, kiosks, lampposts? I built half this district shaking hands. Presence is not guilt — unless you need it to be.
carol: I heard voices, yes. The paper seller and someone in a fine coat. By the time I reached the window, rain streaked the glass and the street was empty. Words dissolve quicker than steam.
He misplaced a file once and begged for miracles. I told him history always returns — even if men don't.
If prints of mine linger on that kiosk, they pay for the morning paper. I don’t climb over counters — my shoes protest the idea.
issac: Workshop closes late. Shutters scream like dying engines. If I fought anyone, half the block would’ve heard. I fix problems — don’t create them in alleys.
He wanted illegal power routes — taps hidden behind walls. I said no. A licence feeds families longer than favour.
If my fingerprints rest on that lamppost, it’s from idle talk about football. Engineers lean; murderers shove.

successEnding:
{culprit} exhales like a man relieved the waiting is over.

Too many deaths. Too many wills shifting like tides. Another briefcase gone, another partner silent. Lawson’s story folds when you line them in order — five victims, one survivor with pockets swelling.

He straightens his tie, offers wrists like concessions. ‘Markets reward consolidation,’ he mutters.
Tonight, the papers print his name — finally below the fold.
failureEnding:
You drag {accused} in — the archivist with thin windows, or the engineer with loud shutters.
The report reads neatly. Too neatly.

Hours later Wren calls:
Another briefcase resurfaces on the black market, pages torn out — evidence curated like art.
The signature buyer? Someone traced back to {culprit}.

Block 2 tightens. The wrong suspect cools in holding.
The real suit walks home under headlines he helped write.
